column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.StanzaNER|value
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Relationships|Relationship|BT_webanno.custom.StanzaNER
#Text=Also known as : Momia de Cerro El Plomo The first high-altitude frozen mummy found in Chile .
#Text=It was located and then hidden by looters who eventually sold it to the government .

#Text=Images via El Museo Nacional de Historia Natural Inka Frozen Mummies During the Inka Empire , individuals ( usually children ) were brought to remote high-altitude locations and ritually sacrificed .
#Text=Because of the extreme cold , their bodies were unintentionally mummified , preserving their skin , hair , soft tissue , clothing , and the ritual objects associated with them .
#Text=The bodies are linked to ‘ capacocha ’ , or human sacrifice as an offering associated with fertility .
#Text=Capacocha occurred during important events , for example the death of the monarch , when stability and order were sought from the gods .
#Text=Physically perfect children were selected for the ritual and taken via holy procession through the empire to a sacred mountain .
#Text=They were fed coca leaves and maize beer ( chicha ) along the way and during the ceremony , presumably to keep them docile .
#Text=They were then killed via strangulation or a blow to the head , or left to die of exposure .
#Text=The remarkable state of preservation of these bodies allows for a detailed analysis of Inka life and death .
#Text=It also attracts looters seeking rare textile and feather artefacts in near-perfect condition .
#Text=The view from atop Cerro El Plomo .

#Text=Image via El Museo Nacional de Historia Natural Looting of the Cerro El Plomo Child In late January 1954 , Guillermo Chacón Carrasco , Luis Gerardo Ríos Barrueto , and Jaime Ríos Abarca left the village of Puente Alto and climbed Cerro El Plomo , a peak in the Chilean Andes .
#Text=Chacón was a treasure hunter and looter of archaeological sites and the group ’ s intent was to dig at three ancient structures upon the mountain in search of artefacts to sell .
#Text=Chacón had previously looted sites on the mountain and had found some ancient silver items ( Museo Nacional de Historia Natural nd ) .
#Text=The men dug in a number of spots on the mountain where they found gold and silver camelid figurines and several other ritual offerings .
#Text=On 1 February , at an altitude of 5,400 metres , the group encountered the frozen body of a sacrificed Inka child .
#Text=The group deposited the body in a cave and returned to Puente Alto with only the associated artefacts and ritual objects ( Museo Nacional de Historia Natural nd ) .
#Text=Several weeks later the group decided to travel to Santiago in hopes of selling the objects in their possession .
#Text=The Museo Histórico Nacional refused to see them , but Dr Grete Mostny , head of Anthropology from 1943 until 1964 at the Museo Nacional de Historia Natural , met with the men on 16 February .
#Text=Mostny asked that the men return at the start of March when the museum director , Humberto Fuenzalida would be present .
#Text=Meanwhile , Mostny went to Puente Alto to search for the stashed mummy .
#Text=The looters heard about this and removed the body from the cave on 8 March .
#Text=When the men returned to Santiago on 17 March , Fuenzalida attempted to buy the ritual objects but a price could not be immediately agreed upon .
#Text=Eventually , the looters were paid 45,000 pesos for the body and the ritual objects that were discovered with it .
#Text=About the mummy The mummy was found to be that of a perfectly preserved Inka boy who died at the approximate age of 8 .
#Text=His hair had been styled into over 200 small braids tied with cord .
#Text=His face had been painted with red and ochre stripes .
#Text=He was dressed as a high-status individual in a red wool shirt trimmed with white leather fringe , a red wool mantel , and leather embroidered moccasins .
#Text=He wore a silver armband and a headdress of black wool topped with condor feathers .
#Text=A bag with the body contained locks of his hair , his nail clippings , and his baby teeth .

#Text=Based on his clothing , the boy is thought to have come from the part of the Inka Empire called the Collasuyu which includes the Peru/Bolivia Altiplano and parts of northern Chile and Argentina .
#Text=He is thought to have died from exposure after being placed in a rectangular sunken chamber atop the mountain ( Museo Nacional de Historia Natural nd ) .
#Text=The body is now kept in the Museo Nacional de Historia Natural and is considered their most valuable anthropological piece ( Museo Nacional de Historia Natural nd ) .
#Text=It is preserved in a special chamber with a humidity of between 42 and 45 per cent and a temperature between -2 and -4 degrees Celsius .
#Text=The body is no longer on display at the museum in accordance with a UNESCO recommendation to not display human remains , but visitors may view a replica .
